customer_name: Otters and Others Zoo and Conservation

citations.narrative:
On March 11, 2025, a video was posted on the facility’s social media showing the ~10 yr old male neutered dromedary
camel reaching over his fence and grabbing with his mouth the head of a woman who walked directly up to his primary
enclosure fencing. No injury to the camel or the woman was reported. During the inspection, the facility confirmed that it is
their facility and camel in the video and that no facility attendant was present at the time of the event. No public barrier is
present around the camel enclosure.
Lack of sufficient distance and/or public barrier and no readily identifiable employee can allow for contact between and
risk of harm or injury to the animal and the public.
Risk to the animal and the public must be minimized by ensuring that sufficient distance and/or public barriers are utilized
between the animal and the viewing public to protect the safety of the animals and the public.
To be corrected by 6/1/2025.

The fencing on the south side of the ~10 yr old male neutered dromedary camel enclosure was constructed of tubular
steel cattle gates supported by metal T posts. The panels were not attached to a middle post, are leaning outward, and
were bent. The panels were sitting directly on the ground and the camel had his foot partially through the bottom rung.
The camel could push through an unattached fence and escape or become entrapped in the panels causing injury or
harm. Failure to properly maintain facilities can result in injury or harm to the animals.
All enclosures and facilities must be constructed of such material and such strength as appropriate for the animals
involved. Facilities must be structurally sound and must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury
and to properly contain them.
To be corrected by 6/15/25
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
